p: Miyazawa et al. [ 45] isolated three polymethoxy flavonoid-type compounds, namely, tetra- O-methylscutellarein, sinensetin, and nobiletin from C. aurantium. These compounds caused marked downstream regulation of a variety of gene expressions and thus showed strong antimutagenic activity. Wang and coworkers [ 46] summarized the anticancer effects of polymethoxyflavones with detailed molecular mechanisms. The various amines and flavonoids have been quantitatively analyzed in C. aurantium using liquid chromatography [ 47, 48]. Hesperidin has been isolated from C. aurantium [ 49]. It displayed a significant apoptotic effect against liver cell lines, HepG2 cells, by mediating through the upstream regulation of mitogen-activated protein kinase ERK1/2 [ 50].
